results.title: Of human rights
results.brief_description: An incident involving economic and racial prejudice among children is used to dramatise the importance of bringing to the attention of the peoples of the world the rights of all human beings as set forth in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

results.title: Of human bondage. Rain
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures, United Artists, Art Cinema Corporation, Pandro S. Berman, Joseph Schenck, John Cromwell and Lewis Milestone
results.brief_description: Two Somerset Maugham novels, which became classic films are here presented on one video. In “Of human bondage” Bette Davis made her name as a cheap and vulgar cafe waitress who taunts and ridicules a besotted Leslie Howard, as a crippled professor. Joan Crawford stars in “Rain” as the bad girl Sadie Thompson who attracts the fanatic obsessions of a missionary, which leads to her spiritual reformation. Set during an epidemic on South Sea Pago Pago island, the film caused much controversy on its release.

results.title: Of hopscotch and little girls
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Marcel Simard, Monique Simard and Marquise Lepage
results.brief_description: This documentary takes up the game of hopscotch - played by girls universally - as a means of discussing the many injustices and hardships that also link the lives of girl children across cultures. Many girls are compelled to take on the responsibilities and concerns of adults caring for younger siblings or working full time to support themselves and their families. This film provides an eclectic portrait of girls’ lives from a diverse range of cultural perspectives. From female circumcision to child prostitution and the emotional desolation of a life lived as a virtual domestic slave, many of these girls’ life lessons have been harsh ones. Their touch points with childhood are the games they play with friends, in the street, in the school yard, and the back yard. Girls in six countries—India, Thailand, Yemen, Peru, Burkina Faso and Haiti—speak of the ways their childhoods have been disrupted sometime purely because they were born female. A deeply moving documentary that contributes to the struggle to eliminate discrimination against young girls.

results.title: Of dreams and reasons
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Malcolm Smith, Karl McPhee and Ben Lewin
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Migrant experience”.
Illustrates the motivations of individuals and various ethnic groups who migrated to Australia. Looks at the convict experience, the Irish, British, northern and southern European and Pacific Islander immigrant experiences, as well as the experiences of recent refugees from Indo-China, Lebanon, Uganda, Timor and Chile. Also considers the accuracy of Australian government promotional literature and films produced to attract migrants in the postwar period.

results.title: Of day of night
results.brief_description: This experimental interactive CD-ROM explores the intersections of narrative, subjectivity and interactivity. A hybrid of cinematic, textual and interactive elements, it finds resonances between dream experience and the unexpected associations inherent in new media forms. A map of sorts. A handful of objects. A problem with dreaming. Found objects and their imagined traces and histories assist a woman who has a problem with dreaming.

results.title: Of bards and beggars
results.brief_description: An interesting documentary about the Raikas of Rajasthan, India, and their 400 year old religious tradition of Jagraan, a prayer ritual to a folk deity known as Pabuji. Pabuji is a virtuous being who looks after his people and their animals especially during times of sickness but also in health. Raikas believe that cattle and camels are their wealth and if an animal is sick, a prayer will be made to Pabuji. The Jagraan consists of an all night epic recitation by a folk musician and singer known as a Bhopa who recounts the legend and deeds of Pajubi to an audience made up mostly of livestock herders. Although a religious event it is also seen to be entertainment for the community. Sadly though, the practice of Jagraan is under threat as village herders are being pushed out by agribusiness and limestone mining. These industries have taken their land which has led to a decrease in grazing land for their herds. At the same time there is no government support and construction sites are appearing all over rural Rajasthan. The old traditional ways of Bhopas with their musical instruments and costume dress is also disappearing due to the diminishing rural population and modern technology in the form of radio and television. More and more they are performing in the hospitality and tourist industry. Contains personal narratives by Raika herders and excerpts from the recitation. Partially funded by the Australia India Council.

results.title: Oedipus Rex. No. 4. The Recovery of Oedipus
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Massachusetts Council for the Humanities and Michael Roemer
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how Greek tragedy considers the status of man as being somewhere between God and beast, always looking for his rightful place. Suitable for upper secondary level.
